author: repliko57

print_settings.Notes:: The files show it oriented as it would be used, but it's designed to be printed the other way up, and oriented with it's major axis along the Y axis of the printer

description.text:
The bed connection points for (especially) the Y axis are pulled out of the plane they "should" run in. This introduces cosine error (or Abbe/sine error depending on how you look at it), both in the Y distance, and in the belt tension. (If you set the belt tension at the end of the travel, then it's slack in the middle; set it in the middle, and it either stretches or pulls out at the ends.)

This block sits below the bed, and returns the belt to horizontal. (The motor side of the belt sits lower than the idler side, so they're horizontal relative to their end points.)

This means that there is a constant belt length, and thus constant tension, allowing more accurate positioning and lower backlash in the system.

The block may be a bit large for standard spacers, since mine were missing and I replaced then with ones I had to hand. I've included the f3d source file so you can trim it to fit. My measured bed-to-extrusion height was 11.54mm, so trim the difference off the top.

This is best printed with the major axis along the Y axis since the allowance is in that direction so that it turns out the right size on an uncorrected bed.

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

Whatever

Notes:

The files show it oriented as it would be used, but it's designed to be printed the other way up, and oriented with it's major axis along the Y axis of the printer

Fitting
  1. Clean up the slots so the belt fits
  2. clean up the ramp sides so they fit in the extrusion channel
  3. Check clearance under the bed, the aim is for 0.5 to 1mm.
Designed in Fusion 360. Ramps and centre block sketched from measured values and extruded. Side walls CSGed on.

description.text:
This is a mount for a lower Z axis bearing for the lead screws. The inside contains enough space for the common 'springy aluminium' lead screw coupling. When assembling the threaded rod through the bearing mount, a gap should be left between the motor shaft and the end of the threader rod to allow the bearing to position the rod in X and Y.

The bearing recess has been sized for the common 608 bearing (8mm ID, 22mm OD, 7mm thk). The model has 21mm centres between smooth rod hole and leadscrew axis.

print_settings.Notes:: The main platform was printed in the traditional orientation, with the bottom of the part on the base plate. The modules were printed in an upside down orientation. This was one so that the extruded holes were printed with precision (when the part was printed on its side the holes did not come out very well). This orientation was also used so that the limited amount of support material used to build the connector section of the module could be more easily removed without affecting the connector feature. The results from 3D printing the modules in different orientations, the drawings for the modules, and the drawings for the main platform are also shown in Figures 11, 12, and 13 at the bottom of the page.

description.text:
*The objective of this research project is to create a robust, easy-to-connect prototyping system for embedded products that can be used with a variety of sensors and the Arduino family of microcontroller boards.

*The two STL files provided are used for 3D printing the main platform and the modules.

*The main platform has holes for an Arduino Uno microcontroller to be mounted onto it. There are also slots in the side of the main platform that allow the USB port and barrel jack to be exposed, which will allow code to be easily uploaded to the Arduino Uno's microcontroller without unscrewing and removing the board.

*Up to three modules can fit inside the platform. The modules are used to hold small ProtoBoards (1 x 1 inch) that are meant to have sensors and wires soldered to them.

*Even with three modules attached to the platform, there is space for a mini breadboard. This breadboard gives space for additional resistors, LEDs, and ICs that are not included within the modules to be used for a prototype.

*The use of the 'Mod Duino' should make a prototype much more portable, without having to worry about connections of sensors or wiring to become disrupted.

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

Mojo

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.007 inches

Infill:

70%

Notes:

The main platform was printed in the traditional orientation, with the bottom of the part on the base plate. The modules were printed in an upside down orientation. This was one so that the extruded holes were printed with precision (when the part was printed on its side the holes did not come out very well). This orientation was also used so that the limited amount of support material used to build the connector section of the module could be more easily removed without affecting the connector feature. The results from 3D printing the modules in different orientations, the drawings for the modules, and the drawings for the main platform are also shown in Figures 11, 12, and 13 at the bottom of the page.

Once the base platform and the three modules were printed, the ‘Mod Duino’ can be assembled. The first step of the assembly is to solder the necessary sensors and wires onto the ProtoBoards. The setup used for soldering and the soldering of the sensors to the ProtoBoards (without wires) is shown in Figures 1 and 2, respectively. Once the soldering is complete, the ProtoBoards are inserted into the top section of the modules. The completed modules are shown below in Figure 3. The wires that are soldered to the boards are inserted through one of the slots on the side of the each module.

Figure 1: Soldering Setup Figure 2: Sensors Soldered to Individual ProtoBoards Figure 3: Final Assembly of Modules

After the modules have been assembled, the Arduino Uno is mounted to the main platform of the ‘Mod Duino’ with screws and nuts smaller than 1/8 of an inch, which is the diameter of the mounting holes on the Arduino board. Two strips of Velcro with sticky backsides were also added to the main platform and the bottom of the bare breadboard. The Velcro was used, instead of permanently mounting the breadboard onto the main platform, so that the breadboard could easily be detached and reattached to the platform. This will make it easier for components like resistors and LEDs to be placed onto the breadboard during the prototyping process.

The breadboard used is a sawed in half (using a vertical band saw) Mini Modular Breadboard from Sparkfun. The mounted Arduino board and the Velcro used to connect the bare breadboard to the main platform are shown in Figure 4. The breadboard was cut in half to fit inside the allowable space without affecting the buses that create an electrical connection within each of the seventeen columns (rows in the configuration of Figure 4).

After the cut breadboard was attached to the main platform, three wires were used to connect the breadboard to the 3.3 volt, 5 volt, and ground pins of the Arduino Uno board (shown in Figure 5). These connections were made to create two power buses (3.3 V and 5 V) and one ground bus on the bare platform. These buses give more space for power and ground connections while prototyping.

Figure 4: Main Platform with mounted Arduino Uno and Velcro used for mounting the Bare Mini Breadboard Figure 5: Creating the 3.3 V, 5 V, and Ground Buses on the Bare Breadboard

Now that the assembly of the main platform and modules is complete, the two components of the ‘Mod Duino’ can come together. The modules are mounted onto the main platform in the configuration shown in Figure 6. This figure gives four different views of the ‘Mod Duino’ final assembly. In this configuration, only the LED module is connected to the breadboard. The module housing the microphone and temperature sensor are not connected to the breadboard, so the wires connected to these modules are held to the side by the hooks on the walls of the base platform. This was done in an effort to keep things within the ‘Mod Duino’ organized.

Figure 6: Final Assembly of ‘Mod Duino’: Bottom (Bottom Left), Top (Top Left), Left Side (Bottom Right), and Isometric (Top Right) Views

Once the assembly mimics that of Figure 6, the ‘Mod Duino” is ready for use. As discussed in previous sections, any type of sensor(s) that is needed for a prototype can be used within the module(s). Additionally, more than one sensor module can be used (via connection to the breadboard) for a given prototyping project.

Testing

After the final assembly of the ‘Mod Duino’ was completed, testing began by verifying that one of the modules could be used to successfully run a program. The example code “Blink” provided by Arduino was used for this verification. The code for this program can be found on the Arduino programming software by navigating through File/Example/0.1Basics/Blink. The circuit configuration and schematic used to run this program is shown in Figure 6.

In order for the code to succesfully be uploaded to the Arduino microcontroller, it is important to check that the correct board and port are selected under the “Tools” tab. The result of running the “Blink” program using the ‘Mod Duino’ is shown in Figure 7. The red light emitting from the sensors in the illustration indicates that the program was able to be run successfully. Uploading and running this code was used as a test case, and its success resulted in the assumption that prototypes involving all the other sensor modules would work as well.

Figure 7: ‘Mod Duino’ Running the Arduino Example Code “Blink”

Abstract One crucial portion of a design project involves the design and build of a prototype. Prototypes are advantageous because they help to reduce a project’s time and cost, identify and address problems early on in the design process, and increase user involvement by confirming a common vision among users and developers. These factors all contribute to delivering a better quality final product. Embedded electromechanical prototypes use programmed electronics and a mechanical device to perform a specific function. Microcontrollers are small computers on integrated circuits that are often used to control the electronics of these embedded prototypes. One set of problems with these prototypes is that the breadboard circuitry can easily become messy and the connections between sensors/actuators and the microcontroller are not reliable. These factors make it difficult to troubleshoot the prototype when a wire accidentally gets disconnected and also makes it difficult to create a portable prototype. There are not many existing products that focus heavily on the integrity of the connections between the main prototyping platform, such as an Arduino microcontroller, and the sensors and actuators used to create the operational portion of the prototype. Previous research indicates that one line of products, the Tibbo Project Systems, focus on robust connections. However, the Tibbo products are complicated to use and are not open source. The widespread popularity and ease of use of the Arduino microcontroller for these simple electromechanical applications make it a perfect candidate for use in a comparable platform. The objective of this research project is to create a robust, easy-to-connect prototyping system for embedded products that can be used with a variety of sensors and the Arduino Uno microcontroller board. The product is expected to form a rigid and clean looking platform that provides a reliable connection between the Arduino and any number of additional modules needed to complete an embedded electromechanical prototype. BackGround There has recently been an uptick in activity among the DIY, Maker, and Hacker communities. These inventors, engineers, and designers work to create products that will benefit themselves or others by collecting information, displaying that information, and sometimes acting on the information. Constructing a prototype is a critical part of the design process used to create a new product. Prototyping is important because it helps to reduce time and cost, identify and address problems early on, confirm a common vision among users and developers, and help the designer deliver a better quality system [3]. Currently, once a member of these communities takes his/her ideas to the prototyping phase, they often times start wiring sensors and actuators to a microcontroller. Unfortunately, many of these prototypes are unorganized and are not easily replicated. It is often difficult to house a microcontroller, breadboard, and an assortment of sensors and actuators in a way that is both aesthetically pleasing and functional (Figure 8). As a result, members of these communities have difficulty creating prototypes that are structurally stable enough to be transported. These complexities create a gap in the market for a modular prototyping platform, which would allow for easy and reliable connection between the microcontroller and sensors that are needed for a particular prototype. The goal is to create an integrated style product, deemed the ‘Mod Duino,’ that will bridge this gap by securing modules (which hold sensors) to a main board that houses the microcontroller. Figure 8: Examples of Typical Breadboards used in Prototyping [4 and 5] The Tibbo Project System shown below in Figure 9 can be used to quickly move through the prototyping process to produce a wide range of presentable projects. The system “features an almost bare board powered by Texas Instruments Sitara processor, and a large area for Tibbit blocks to add features as needed, as well as an enclosure” [6].Tibbo does a great job of providing customers with the ability to choose from a wide variety of Tibbit blocks that include components such as sensors, actuators, power supplies, and USB ports. These blocks can be rigidly attached to the bare board to quickly put together a sturdy and reliable prototype that looks good enough to present. The company also offers bare boards of different sizes, gives you the option of creating a custom board before purchasing, and gives the option of enclosing the entire platform in a box for additional protection. There is one existing product that has distinct advantages which will be implemented in the ‘Mod Duino.’ This platform is the Tibbo Project System. As described in the previous section, the Tibbo has the advantage of creating reliable connections between modules and the microprocessor and providing a clean and professional final presentation, which are some of the primary goals of this research. However, one of the major disadvantages of the Tibbo Project Systems is that they run off TiOS, which not many people are familiar with. Arduino has its own open source coding program, which many more (even inexperienced) engineers have been exposed to. The products Tibbo offers are also relatively expensive, in the range of a couple hundred USD. Tibbo also offers a wide range of modules that include an assortment of components, which would typically be a benefit. The problem is that implementing these modules can easily be confusing for a hobbyist. The modules provided by this company are so advanced that it would take a well-trained electrical engineer to understand and use them effectively. The Tibbo products may work better on the industrial level, but hobbyist and young engineers are much more likely to have an understanding of a basic microcontroller like an Arduino. Creating a system that incorporates an Arduino board would be much more useful for a beginner looking to gain experience with prototyping. Figure 9: Tibbo Project System [7] Arduino offers a range of microcontrollers that are in the thirty to fifty dollar range and are much more common in the United States when compared to the Tibbo Project System. The Arduino family of microcontrollers is also considered to be basic, even for beginners, which means individuals of all experience levels can enjoy the ‘Mod Duino.’ Out of the Arduino family of microcontrollers, the Uno is decidedly the most popular. Due to this fact, the ‘Mod Duino’ will be made to fit this specific microcontroller so that it can meet the needs of the largest number of people. The ‘Mod Duino’ will expand the microcontroller’s prototyping capabilities by adding some of the connectivity features that are so successful in the Tibbo Project System. A wide range of prototyping projects are able to be completed with the ‘Mod Duino,’ because the user should be able to use multiple modules at one time and write unique code to control these modules. Connecting more than one module to the base platform can be beneficial, especially in larger projects that need to include an array of sensors and actuators. The main goal of the product is simplicity through organization on the hardware side of prototyping. The sleek, finished look of the modules and the easy and smooth connection between the modules and the base delivers this simplicity. This solves a common problem in the current prototyping area by making the physical connection between a microcontroller and its sensors/actuators easy, reliable, and aesthetically pleasing. All the components and wiring will neatly be enclosed in the casing of the main board. The purpose of this research is to create a system that can ensure a clean and reliable connection between an Arduino Uno microcontroller and its compatible sensors that might be used in a prototype. This is significant because often times, the wiring used in “low-end” prototyping projects become disconnected, causing them not to work properly. Ensuring these connections will allow the less experienced engineer to spend more time gaining knowledge of different types of sensors, instead of unnecessarily spending time trouble shooting their device. A rigid system would also lead to a better looking prototype, because there will not be any loose or tangled wires. This is important because an aesthetically appealing prototype can more easily be presented and explained than a messy one. The system will also make the prototype portable, which is a challenge for current prototypes that have floating breadboards and microcontrollers that are solely connected by unsoldered wires.
Bill of Materials

Here are the links to all of the references on this page: [1] Aruino Uno made by Jorge Alberto Silva on GrabCAD (used in Solidworks Assembly): https://grabcad.com/library/arduino-uno-reference-design

[5] Messy Breadboard Pic 2: “Flex sensor interfacing with AVR Microcontroller” from https://www.pinterest.com/pin/467600373789612511/

title: Jason Voorhees "Rubber" Duck
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Your waters are no longer safe! The Jason Voorhees Rubber Duck has invaded your ponds, rivers, and lakes!

I created this model to enter into the Tinkercad/Myminifactory Halloween Contest.

Included in this design are single and dual extrusion models for the main body, mask, and weapons.

Most of the parts should have uploaded in the positions I found them easiest to print.

I used Loctite Super Glue to glue the beak and the strap for the mask. Glue is option for the rest of the pieces since they should all fit snugly on their own.
I glued each notch of the strap into the mask slot individually, giving each one time to dry before moving on to the next one.

I dipped the hair in hot water (be careful!) to soften it and pressed it close to his head so the mask will fit properly. I left extra hair on the model so you can clip it afterwards to make it look however you feel. His head will be more cumbersome to put on if you choose to give him hair past his "shoulders".

When putting the mask on (beak and strap should be dry and hair clipped and groomed close to his head), focus on putting the beak into the designated area of the mask. The strap will bend over the head as you slip the beak in.

The eyes are labeled underneath so you know which eye is which from Jason's perspective.

If the eyes, beak, or arms do not not quite fit, it is due to slight over-extrusion. I mostly did not have this issue, but shaving off the extra filament will fix the problem.

This model can actually float, but it is not balanced well due to being heavier in the front.

I hope you all enjoy!

Printing Tips

Main body - .1 layer height, low infill 5-10%

Head - .2 layer height to make the hair print well. I printed at a speed of 50 mm/s with no issues. Low infill.

Arms - .1 layer height, print vertically with a good brim to keep in position, low infill

Mask - .1 layer height, 100% infill, print slow

Mask strap - .1 layer height, print slow

Eyes and beak - .1 layer height, 100% infill, print slow

Machete - .1 layer height, has built-in supports that can be removed easily

Buther's Knife - print vertically, .1 layer height, print slow

Hacksaw - .1 layer height, print slow

description.text:

This is far from perfect but worked well and was a very fun project. I would assume you could scale this to fit an adult hand though I haven't tried.

title: Punk-Rock, Balloon-Popping, Battle Teal™ Drone Top Remix

description.text:
This mod is the apex predator of all Teal drones. No one will get anywhere close to your personal air-space when you're rocking the Punk-Rock, Balloon-Popping, Battle Teal™ Drone Top Remix.

This drone top has been designed for popping balloons and interfering with enemy drone propellers. It sports a front-facing dagger and 4 upper-deck spikes, so you can take down your target doing a nose dive or accelerating up/forward.

Practicality has been kept in mind:

  • 100% 3d-printable
  • aerodynamic
  • can be 3d printed at any layer height
  • front dagger extends beyond propellers for puncturing without interference
  • spikes are not oversize, keeping curb weight minimal

author: ftdesigns

title: Treasure Chest 5mm Plywood with Clasp and Hinges

description.text:
Loved the original design by Sean Flanagan, and Ryan McGeary, so I resized it for 5mm plywood. I also took out the duplicate pieces and redistributed them for 12.5" x 8.5" sheets. My chinese k40 laser has an official cut area of 300mm x 200mm but this size sheet works great, and is easy to cut from a 8' x 4' sheet. I also attached the cut sheet, and if you follow that you can make 8 boxes (with a little cheating on the scrap pieces).

Laser settings are different for all lasers, but my 40W CO2 laser was set at 40% and 400 mm/s for the engraving, and 40% and 5 mm/s for the cutting (single pass). Programs used are Gimp, Inkscape and k40 Whisperer.

The 5mm hobby plywood I got from Lowes ($16) and they will make the 12 cuts for you ($0.25ea). So each gift box could run you $2.50 in material.

Tips: Use a scalpel to help with the places where the laser didn't quite cut deep enough. Assemble the entire clasp, and hinge before gluing them to the box. I used a discarded pin from a pop-rivet which is easy to cut to length, and fits perfectly.

The final assembled size is: 11.25" x 8.25" x 6.25"

It took me about one and a half hours to engrave/cut, and another hour to assemble. The fit is super tight, so you can assemble without glue if you want. I used a little hobby hammer to gentle nudge the pieces together.

Ask me any questions you want - but use online converters for different file formats, and find your own pictures and art, since I am not going to distribute those :)

Enjoy.

title: Sakura Racing D4 Rear Belt Tension Pulley V1

description.text:
I recently bought a new rear drive belt for my Sakura D4 R/C drift car, and I could not find any suitable tension pulleys for sale so I made this one on Tinkerkad. It uses the original screws to the rear of the chassis that hold down the shock tower on the motor side but required

4x M3 screws (length doesn't really matter but 7-10mm should be plenty)
2x 10mm outer, 5mm inner, 3mm thick bearings

Height is adjustable as well as lateral position with the mounting holes for the axle, and fine tuning can be done with the vertical sliding slots.

I have not had a chance to print this yet so there will be further versions if improvements need to be made. Feel free to let me know if there is anything I should focus on.

Edit: more holes added and sharp point removed. Both files are available
Thanks

description.text:
This is a simple bracket that attaches to the chassis of a Commodore 1541 disk drive and allows you to attach a 55mm x 55mm x 10mm 12v fan, which is run at 5v to keep the fan noise at a minimum and still keep the drive cool.
Based on an idea by PetterHans @bwack which he asked me to design and print for him.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fEvbVr-aBXk&t=274s

Various designs of the 1541 exist so it may need slight modification to fit.
In my drive Alps/toaster variant I used rubber fan mounts and still had 2mm clearance
between fan top and the inside of the case. Though because of the semi closed grille design of the case air noise is increase slightly.

Power for the fan is taken from any +5v and GND source.

6/1/18 Have added a 60mm fan version (untested) Just make sure its a 60x60x10mm fan or it won't fit inside the case.

remixed_from.author: DjDemonD
remixed_from.title: Precision Piezo - Piezo20 Hotend Z Probe

description.text:
This is a remix of volcom8190's VORON carriage adapted to work with the piezo probe by DJDemonD.

Basically it is a carriage midsection that allows to mount a slightly modified (no board mounting points) version of the original precision piezo hotend mount.

It also includes a hole to screw a standard plastic bowden coupling into, as sold by e.g. E3D.

Be aware of the following things:

  • This carriage midsection is about 6mm wider than the original VORON carriage, so you'll need longer M3 bolts. The center, left and right carriage sections included in this thing can be used with 50mm bolts.
  • This mount is made for 20mm piezo discs
  • The original fan ducts by volcom won't fit since the hotend sits slightly lower: use the supplied elongated fanduct STLs
  • This thing does not include a (proper) solution for mounting the piezo board. I've included the lazy solution I use: print the box and glue it to your carriage.
  • Both your X travel and Z travel will be reduced (6mm and 5mm, respectively)
  • make sure to remove the bowden coupling in your hotend if you're using a plastic bowden coupling

If your tired of not being able to use your filament switches because the filament keeps slipping off the side this is the solution. To install use a 14mm wrench to unscrew the guide tube fittings. Also, you will want to remove the plastic clamp around the wire harness as its no longer needed with this part. This part squeezes the wire harness just enough to hold everything in place without the need for that ugly annoying clamp. After you slide the part in place carefully screw your guide tube fittings back in and use the 14mm wrench to tighten. If you use a flat wrench there will be just enough of the fitting sticking up above the part to tighten it enough. I did this on purpose as it helps prevent overtightening since the metal it screws into is very brittle. This also makes the part very strong having it a bit thicker on top.

I've printed this in both ABS and PLA however the PLA version is far easier as the ABS version warps easily. Plenty of strength even with the PLA with the print orientation. I did use 75% infill which may be a little overkill but I didn't want it to break. Layer height is 0.1 mm. You can do it with or without supports on the fitting holes. I chose to do it with since having perfectly round holes is essential to the part and they are small easily removed supports anyways.

Hopefully this solves for you one of the major frustrations I have had with this printer as well! Experienced people with this printer know this, but if your new to it. Don't forget if your only using one extruder don't forget to stick a piece of scrap filament in the unused side so the switch isn't tripped stopping the printer from printing.

Printer:

BIBO Touch X Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

75%

title: iPhonograph Samsung Galaxy S Apple iPhone 6 7 8 X Plus Dock Holder (Speaker on Bottom Phones)

description.text:
Drop a like and follow me on Twitter and Instagram for all sorts of new stuff and free downloads!! My profiles are new but Ill be adding lots of unique content in the near future. And as always, lets see those makes!

https://twitter.com/CMurrayDesigns

https://www.instagram.com/christophermurray.design/

If you print the record with a .4 or less nozzle, you will see the grooves in the record!!

It has been brought to my attention that this device will also work well with Samsung Galaxy model phones. The phone insert dimensions are 88mm x 19mm, and from what I can tell this will also likely accommodate a Galaxy Note sized phone as well! Possibly its case too! Its hard to stay current and design with every single phone configuration in mind. If you have a phone with speakers on the very bottom by the charger cable, please list your phone model in the comments below. This device will work with any phone speakers on the bottom, located on either side of the charge cable, and within above dimensions. Enjoy!

140 years of audio technology in one slick desktop unit. Add your charger cable through the bottom hole to charge you device while listening through the phonograph. The purpose of this design is to further amplify the sound of the iPhone by channeling the sound through the device and out the bell of the phonograph (gramophone). Focusing the direction of the sound through the bell makes the sound seem twice as loud. This model has been printed successfully on Stratasys F370. It should print well on any printer but starting here with these printers, I know that the design can be produced and assembled properly.

Most pieces can be printed with no or minimal supports with the exception of the bell. The bell will test your 3d printing skills and your printers skills.

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

Dimension SST 1200es

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This is a large print/assembly. Roughly 4.5" x 9.5" footprint. The bell will be the most difficult piece to print. You will need supports when printing this piece. When I printed this, I printed it with the mouth of the bell directly on the bed. Same material supports will work. The rest of the pieces including the base could be printed without supports.

Print the Case shim adapter out of a Flexible material if you have it available. This piece helps retain the charger cord once in the base. If no flex material is available, any material will work, but flex is nice here.

Design Method

For this design I used Solidworks 2017 to create all pieces. I also used Solidworks add-in Photoview 360 for the rendering of assembly and section views.

comments.text:
Made it. Love it. Thanks.
(it would be nice if the bell stay higher over the record platform, maybe changing the angle of it... just an idea).
comments.author: Almaluis

comments.text: Glad you like it!  You are right about the bell.   I had that same thought cross my mind while designing this model.  I based this model off an old gramophone picture and it had a low slung bell.  Most others seem to have more clearance above the record.  But the time I had allotted my self for this design was dwindling and I was trying to make sure proportion, function, and fit.  Maybe ill revisit that idea and the proper splitting of the bell so it can be printed in two colors as a whole, or printed in pieces then assembled.  Thanks for the feedback.

comments.text: Yes I made the opening oversized to allow for the large cases.  When building I used otterbox and Lifeproofs largest case dimensions , and then slightly offset those to allow for some wiggle room.  The shim helps cut out some of the front to back wiggle room, also helps to retain cord.  I would print the shim anyways to see how your phone fits with it.  Its a very small piece, easy print and will likely make your phone more stable in the holder.  I would love to see another print of this assembly.  Happy Printing!

print_settings.Infill:: 100% for Bolts, Mount Nut, Wing Nut, and COB Bracket.  20% for Light Bar Bracket

description.text: I designed this LED light bar to provide a lot of light with a compact design while not being expensive. The COB LED's and power supply were purchased on AliExpress for under $6 USD (links are provided in the misc. notes section). The COB LED's are on a bracketed adjustable mount. The light bar bracket is held on the 2020 frame with a bolt and nut that slides into the notch on the 2020 aluminum frame. All parts are printed with ABS. I chose ABS as it offers better heat resistance because COB LED's do get warm and strength because the bolt and nuts are under stress. I removed the frame on the COB LED's to aid in heat dissipation and to minimize overall form factor. The pictures show my old style wing nuts and bolts. The files attached are the upgraded version for better aesthetics and fit. This project took some time to design as I wanted to make all the bolts and nuts from plastic, which is a lot harder than i anticipated. I am new to designing and printing so I welcome constructive criticism and tips. Please print, enjoy, share, and leave comments.

title: Samsung S3 or S5 Auto vent mount

description.text:
This is an auto mount for a Galaxy S3 or S5 WITH a hard cover. There is a little space given on the left and right so if you have a large case it should be fine. Without a cover it might slide around a bit but it won't fall out. Its designed to have the S3 sit in landscape mode. Might make a portrait one later.
Unfortunately the left bracket is close to the volume button so it may interfere with the use of that. I'm too lazy to adjust it, but maybe later I will.
Oh it will also work as a phone stand as well if you don't feel like putting it in your car.
UPDATE(3/4/14):DON'T USE PLA! I didn't put much thought into it at the time. It worked and fit great until i turned the heater on last night.... Bad idea... after about a half hour the vent clips spread open and it dropped out. SOOOO in conclusion, use ABS or something heat resistant

I used PLA, might have to print it in ABS later since its going to be in the car it might melt on a summer day.
The clips you should probably print with Support... clean up is a pain but it works out nicely.
The phone holder itself needs no support, I seemed to have worked out the angles correctly.
Obviously you need two

title: Ball Bearing Filament Guide for Monoprice Select Mini

description.text:
This Design is an overkill filament guide for the MP Select Mini. I created this because I had some spare bearings laying around.

There are three parts to the design.

  • Filament Guide - This will be screwed to the top of your MP Select mini. It os only fastened using the front most screw on the top of the printer. There is a hole that slides around the second screw to secure the guide without having to remove the rear screw

-Bearing Guide - This should fit around your bearing and wil create a groove to properly direct your filament.

-Bearing Rod - Simply slide through the center of the bearing to hold it in place.

title: CR-10 E3D V6 dual Extruder mount Mesh

description.text:
I've meshed this E3D V6 dual extruder mount out of: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2182924 & https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2274499 to fit my needs.
It's a dual extruder mount with one filament cooler and after mounting the two E3D V6 it's about the same hight as the original CR-10 Extruder.

The Hotend Cooler are from this source: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:354723 and where a little bit redisigned for the M3 screws and this is for the stock 40mm FAN of the CR-10 (please note the hotend cooler must be mounted to the E3D V6 before mounting it to the CR-10 and that the left hotend cooler is a little bit out of center).

Thank's to the creators of these three designs.

ATTENTION: Please be sure that both hotends about the same hight so that they don't interfear with the bed.
Also the first extruder must be on te right side and the second extroder on the left.

Offset for the extruder two X-33.5 und Y0.8

Set this by typing in the terminal:
M218 T0 X0.0 Y0.0 (to set extruder0 to x0 and y0)
M218 T1 X-35.5 Y0.8 (to set the extruder1 offset)
M500 (to save the settings)
Start printing and adjust the settings if they don't fit on your mount (also works on the fly and don't forget to save with command M500)

Parts needed:
1x 50mm x 15mm Blower Fan
1x M3 x 20mm Socket Head Bolt (For the Blower Fan)
2x M3 x 10mm Socket Head Bolts (Please use treadlock glue for the extruder carrier)
1x M3 Nut (in my oppinion Nylon nuts are the best)
4x Metal Screws for the top mount brackets
8x M3 x 40mm for the two Hotend Coolers

Creality CR-10

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

40

Hotend 210 °C
Bed 50 °C
Verbatim PLA white
3 Bottom / Top Layers
40% Infill

description.text:
This is a gimbal for the mobius Action camera. This is meant to be front mounted and not hanging underneath. This is actually a mix of the two designs. I have included photos of the parts that will be printed to make the gimbal.
Note: This is not my design but two of Turbi's designs put together for a front mounted Gimbal for the mobius.
I am in the works of printing one right now so the photos above are not actually the real thing.

comments.text: Is this any different then the mobius gimbal that Turbi posted?
comments.author: jcostello85

comments.text: Did you read the description? No it's not, I just put it together for a top mounted gimbal.
comments.author: jcostello85

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: avdl72

comments.text:
But then the gimbal is on top of the copter, not in front. To really have it in front (to be able to have the cam look down 90°), you could mount the stand5 part on top of the vibration platform but with the holes that are supposed to be fixed to the roll motor. Then the stand5 is bending downwards and you could mount the roll motor at the two holes that are originally supposed to be fixed to the vib mount.
Complicated to describe but so simple...as it is now, it's supposed to hang underneath or stand on top, but for facing to the front the holes would have to be reversed or you could just drill a hole for the motor shaft or cut it out in the stl file.
Then you have a truly forward facing gimbal.
comments.author: gojibogyo

comments.text:
I assume we are talking about a spider style quad? I have mounted mine on a custom qav400/500. You don't get any props in the view and you can point it straight down without issue so I don't have a problem with the design.
Unfortunately, my gimbal controller arrived and it was dead on arrival so I have ordered a martinez v3. My quad crashed into a massive pile of mud yesterday so I decided to rebuild the quad to get all the mud off.
comments.author: gojibogyo

comments.text: I don't see how this is "front-mounted" and "not hanging underneath". Like the design and printed it but to have it front mounted the holes in the motorless arm would have to be on the other side. Then you could mount it on top of the vibration platform and it would stand out in front. Could you upload the openscad files, too, if they exist?
comments.author: gojibogyo

comments.text: I don't understand what you mean. I just drilled two holes in the clean side of my quad and bolted the part stand5 to the frame facing forwards.
